Germany: Germany has over 1,500 breweries and is famous for its beer purity law called Reinheitsgebot.
The Berlin Wall fell in 1989, reuniting East and West Germany after 28 years of division.
Germany is home to the world's largest folk festival, Oktoberfest, held annually in Munich.
France: France is the most visited country in the world, welcoming over 89 million tourists annually.
The Eiffel Tower was originally intended to be a temporary structure for the 1889 World's Fair.
France has won the most Nobel Prizes in Literature of any country.
Italy: Italy has more UNESCO World Heritage Sites than any other country in the world.
The piano was invented in Italy around 1700 by Bartolomeo Cristofori.
Italy is home to three active volcanoes: Vesuvius, Etna, and Stromboli.
Spain: Spain has the second-highest number of UNESCO World Heritage Sites in the world.
The Spanish language is spoken by over 500 million people worldwide.
Spain produces about half of the world's olive oil.
Poland: Poland is home to 17 UNESCO World Heritage Sites, including the historic center of Krakow.
The Polish alphabet has 32 letters, including 9 vowels.
Poland has one of the world's oldest salt mines, the Wieliczka Salt Mine, dating back to the 13th century.
Netherlands: The Netherlands is the most densely populated country in Europe.
About 26% of the Netherlands is below sea level, protected by an extensive system of dikes.
The Netherlands has more museums per square mile than any other country in the world.
Belgium: Belgium produces over 220 varieties of beer and has more than 180 breweries.
Belgium is famous for inventing french fries, despite the name suggesting they're from France.
Belgium has three official languages: Dutch, French, and German.
Switzerland: Switzerland has four official languages: German, French, Italian, and Romansh.
The Swiss consume more chocolate per capita than any other nation in the world.
Switzerland is home to the world's longest tunnel, the Gotthard Base Tunnel.
Austria: Austria is the birthplace of classical music composers Mozart, Beethoven, and Strauss.
The Sound of Music was filmed in Austria, specifically in and around Salzburg.
Austria has the highest proportion of organic farmland in Europe.
Czech Republic: The Czech Republic has the highest beer consumption per capita in the world.
Prague's astronomical clock, installed in 1410, is the third-oldest in the world.
The Czech Republic is home to more than 2,000 castles and chateaux.
Hungary: Hungarian is one of the most difficult languages to learn, unrelated to most European languages.
Hungary has won more Olympic medals per capita than any other nation.
The Rubik's Cube was invented by Hungarian architect Ern≈ë Rubik in 1974.
Slovakia: Slovakia has the highest number of castles and chateaux per capita in the world.
The geographical center of Europe is located in Slovakia.
Slovakia is the world's largest per-capita car producer.
Slovenia: Slovenia is one of the most forested countries in Europe, with forests covering 60% of its territory.
Lake Bled in Slovenia has a church on an island that can only be reached by boat.
Slovenia is home to the world's oldest vine, which is over 400 years old.
Croatia: Croatia has over 1,000 islands along its Adriatic coastline.
The necktie (cravat) was invented in Croatia and gets its name from Croatian soldiers.
Croatia is home to the world's smallest town, Hum, with only about 30 residents.
Serbia: Serbia is one of the world's largest producers of raspberries.
The Serbian language can be written in both Cyrillic and Latin scripts.
Serbia has one of the oldest archaeological sites in Europe, Lepenski Vir.
Bosnia and Herzegovina: Bosnia and Herzegovina is shaped roughly like a triangle with a small coastline on the Adriatic Sea.
The country is home to one of the last remaining primeval forests in Europe.
Montenegro: Montenegro means 'Black Mountain' in most Western European languages.
Montenegro has the deepest canyon in Europe, the Tara River Canyon.
Montenegro was the first country to declare war on Japan in the Russo-Japanese War of 1904.
Albania: Albania is home to over 750,000 bunkers built during the communist era.
Mother Teresa, the Nobel Peace Prize winner, was of Albanian ethnicity.
Albania has three UNESCO World Heritage Sites despite being one of Europe's smallest countries.
North Macedonia: North Macedonia is landlocked and mountainous, with over 50 peaks above 2,000 meters.
The country is known as the birthplace of the Cyrillic alphabet.
North Macedonia has one of the oldest observatories in the world, dating back to the 2nd century BC.
Greece: Greece has more than 6,000 islands and islets, but only 227 are inhabited.
Greece is the birthplace of democracy, philosophy, and the Olympic Games.
Greek is one of the oldest recorded living languages, with over 3,400 years of written history.
Bulgaria: Bulgaria is the oldest country in Europe that hasn't changed its name since it was first established.
Bulgaria is famous for its rose oil production, producing 85% of the world's rose oil.
The Cyrillic alphabet originated in Bulgaria during the 9th century.
Romania: Romania is home to the world's heaviest building, the Palace of the Parliament in Bucharest.
Transylvania, famous for the Dracula legend, is located in Romania.
Romania has the fastest internet speed in the world according to some studies.
Moldova: Moldova has the largest wine cellar in the world, stretching for 200 kilometers underground.
Moldova is the least visited country in Europe, making it a hidden gem for travelers.
The country is landlocked and is one of the poorest countries in Europe.
Ukraine: Ukraine is the largest country entirely within Europe by land area.
Ukraine is known as the 'Breadbasket of Europe' due to its fertile soil.
The Chernobyl nuclear disaster occurred in Ukraine in 1986.
Belarus: Belarus is known as the 'Lungs of Europe' due to its vast forests covering 40% of the country.
Belarus has two official languages: Belarusian and Russian.
The country is famous for its traditional wooden architecture and crafts.
Lithuania: Lithuania was the first Soviet republic to declare independence in 1990.
Basketball is the most popular sport in Lithuania, and the country has a strong basketball tradition.
Lithuania has one of the fastest internet speeds in the world.
Latvia: Latvia has the widest waterfall in Europe, the Ventas Rumba.
Riga, the capital of Latvia, has the largest collection of Art Nouveau buildings in the world.
Latvia is one of the least religious countries in the world.
Estonia: Estonia is one of the most digitally advanced countries in the world, with e-residency programs.
Estonia has over 1,500 islands, but only the two largest are permanently inhabited.
Skype was invented in Estonia by Estonian developers.
Finland: Finland has more saunas than cars, with over 2 million saunas for 5.5 million people.
Finland is known as the 'Land of a Thousand Lakes' but actually has 188,000 lakes.
Finland consistently ranks as one of the happiest countries in the world.
Sweden: Sweden has not been at war for over 200 years, making it one of the most peaceful countries.
IKEA, H&M, Volvo, and Spotify all originated in Sweden.
Sweden recycles so efficiently that it imports waste from other countries to fuel its power plants.
Norway: Norway has the longest coastline in Europe, stretching over 25,000 kilometers including fjords.
Norway is home to the midnight sun phenomenon, where the sun doesn't set for months in summer.
Norway has the largest sovereign wealth fund in the world, built from oil revenues.
Denmark: Denmark consistently ranks as one of the happiest countries in the world.
LEGO was invented in Denmark in 1958 by Ole Kirk Christiansen.
Denmark has more than 7,000 kilometers of coastline despite being a small country.
Iceland: Iceland runs almost entirely on renewable energy from geothermal and hydroelectric sources.
Iceland has no mosquitoes, making it one of the few countries in the world without them.
Iceland has more writers and artists per capita than any other country in the world.
United Kingdom: The United Kingdom is made up of four countries: England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland.
London has been the largest city in Europe for most of the past 200 years.
The UK has produced more Nobel Prize winners per capita than any other country.
Ireland: Ireland is known as the 'Emerald Isle' due to its lush green landscape.
Irish is the first official language of Ireland, though English is more widely spoken.
Ireland has won the Eurovision Song Contest seven times, more than any other country.
Portugal: Portugal is the oldest nation-state in Europe, with borders established in 1139.
Portuguese is spoken by over 250 million people worldwide across multiple continents.
Portugal produces half of the world's cork, harvested from cork oak trees.
Turkey: Turkey is the only country that spans two continents, Europe and Asia.
Istanbul was once the capital of both the Byzantine and Ottoman empires.
Turkey is famous for inventing Turkish coffee and the Turkish bath.
Russia: Russia is the largest country in the world, spanning 11 time zones.
The Trans-Siberian Railway is the longest railway line in the world, stretching 9,289 kilometers.
Russia has more forest area than any other country, containing about 60% of the world's coniferous forest.
China: China has the world's largest population with over 1.4 billion people.
The Great Wall of China is over 21,000 kilometers long and took over 2,000 years to build.
China is home to the world's highest mountain, Mount Everest, on its border with Nepal.
Japan: Japan consists of 6,852 islands, though only about 430 are inhabited.
Japan has the world's oldest continuous monarchy, dating back over 2,600 years.
Japan is the birthplace of karaoke, instant noodles, and the bullet train.
India: India is the world's largest democracy with over 900 million eligible voters.
India has 22 official languages and over 1,600 spoken languages.
India is the birthplace of four major world religions: Hinduism, Buddhism, Jainism, and Sikhism.
Brazil: Brazil is home to the Amazon rainforest, which produces 20% of the world's oxygen.
Brazil has won the FIFA World Cup five times, more than any other country.
Portuguese is the official language of Brazil, making it the largest Portuguese-speaking country.
United States: The United States has the world's largest economy and military budget.
The US has 63 national parks, including Yellowstone, the world's first national park.
The United States is the third most populous country in the world with over 330 million people.
Canada: Canada has the longest coastline of any country in the world, stretching over 202,000 kilometers.
Canada has two official languages: English and French.
Canada contains 20% of the world's fresh water in its lakes and rivers.
Mexico: Mexico is the birthplace of chocolate, vanilla, and chili peppers.
Mexico has 67 national languages, making it the country with the most indigenous languages in the Americas.
Mexico City is built on a lake and is sinking at a rate of 6-8 inches per year.
Australia: Australia is the only country that is also a continent.
Australia has more species of venomous snakes than any other country.
The Great Barrier Reef in Australia is the largest living structure on Earth, visible from space.
Egypt: Egypt is home to the Great Pyramid of Giza, the only surviving wonder of the ancient world.
The Nile River, which flows through Egypt, is the longest river in the world.
Egypt has over 100 pyramids, not just the famous ones at Giza.
South Africa: South Africa has 11 official languages, the most of any country in the world.
South Africa is the only country to voluntarily dismantle its nuclear weapons program.
South Africa is home to the world's largest diamond mine, the Big Hole in Kimberley.
Morocco: Morocco is the only African country with coastlines on both the Atlantic Ocean and Mediterranean Sea.
The University of Al Quaraouiyine in Morocco is considered the oldest continuously operating university in the world.
Morocco is famous for its traditional handicrafts, including carpets, pottery, and leather goods.
Kenya: Kenya is home to the Great Migration, one of the most spectacular wildlife events on Earth.
Mount Kenya is the second-highest mountain in Africa after Mount Kilimanjaro.
Kenya is the birthplace of long-distance running, producing many world-class marathon runners.
Nigeria: Nigeria is the most populous country in Africa with over 200 million people.
Nigeria has over 500 indigenous languages, making it one of the most linguistically diverse countries.
Nigeria is Africa's largest oil producer and has the continent's largest economy.
